|510 u.s. 1307|"OCTOBER TERM
Syllabus
Opinion in Chambers
CAPITOL SQUARE REVIEW AND ADVISORY BOARD ET AL. v. PINETTE ET AL.
ON APPLICATION FOR STAY OF INJUNCTION No. A-517. Decided December 23

An application to stay an injunction requiring applicants to allow respondents to erect a large Latin cross in front of the Ohio Statehouse is denied. The privately owned cross is currently in place and scheduled to be removed tomorrow. Whatever harm may flow from allowing the cross to remain in place for one more day has probably already occurred; because the legal issues are presumably capable of repetition
column2: the case is unlikely to become moot when the cross is removed. Applicants may be well advised to marshal their arguments in a certiorari petition that can be considered with appropriate deliberation.

Today is Thursday
column3: 1993. Yesterday evening applicants filed with me
column4: in my capacity as Circuit Justice for the Sixth Circuit

column6: the Knights of the Ku Klux Klan and its leading officers
column7: to erect a large Latin cross in front of the Ohio Statehouse in Columbus
column8: Ohio. As I understand the situation
column9: the cross is in place now and is scheduled to be removed tomorrow. If I were to grant the application forthwith
column10: it would be removed today-unless
column11: of course
column12: respondents could persuade the full Court to reinstate the injunction.

Indeed

officials opposes the display of the cross and any messages which might reasonably be associated with this display by the Klan. Moreover

column4: the reasonable observer should conclude that the government is expressing its toleration of religious and secular pluralism."" No. C2-931162 (SD Ohio
column5: Dec. 21

column1: In their application
column2: applicants do not dispute the accuracy of that finding.

column1: Whether or not applicants' legal position is sound (and my opinion in Allegheny County v. American Civil Liberties Union
column5: explains why I am not unresponsive to their arguments)
column6: they must shoulder the burden of persuading me that irreparable harm will ensue if I do not grant their application. Frankly
column7: it is my opinion that whatever harm may flow from allowing the privately owned cross to remain in place until tomorrow has probably already occurred. Moreover
column8: because the legal issues are presumably capable of repetition

Syllabus
UNITED STATES v. JAMES DANIEL GOOD REAL PROPERTY ET AL.
CERTIORARI TO THE UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR THE NINTH CIRCUIT
No. 92-1180. Argued October 6
Four and one-half years after police found drugs and drug paraphernalia in claimant Good's home and he pleaded guilty to promoting a harmful drug in violation of Hawaii law
column2: the United States filed an in rem action in the Federal District Court
column3: seeking forfeiture of his house and land
column5: on the ground that the property had been used to commit or facilitate the commission of a federal drug offense. Following an ex parte proceeding
column6: a Magistrate Judge issued a warrant authorizing the property's seizure
column7: and the Government seized the property without prior notice to Good or an adversary proceeding. In his claim for the property and answer to the Government's complaint
column8: Good asserted that he was deprived of his property without due process of law and that the action was invalid because it had not been timely commenced. The District Court ordered that the property be forfeited
column9: but the Court of Appeals reversed. It held that the seizure without prior notice and a hearing violated the Due Process Clause
column10: and remanded the case for a determination whether the action
column11: although filed within the 5-year period provided by 19 U. S. C.  1621
column12: was untimely because the Government failed to follow the internal notification and reporting requirements of  1602-1604.

column1: Held:
1. Absent exigent circumstances
column2: the Due Process Clause requires the Government to afford notice and a meaningful opportunity to be heard before seizing real property subject to civil forfeiture. Pp. 48-62.

column1: (a) The seizure of Good's property implicates two"" 'explicit textual source[s] of constitutional protection
column2: '"" the Fourth Amendment and the Fifth. Soldal v. Cook County
column4: 70. While the Fourth Amendment places limits on the Government's power to seize property for purposes of forfeiture
column5: it does not provide the sole measure of constitutional protection that must be afforded property owners in forfeiture proceedings. Gerstein v. Pugh
column8: distinguished. Where the Government seizes property not to preserve evidence of criminal wrongdoing but to assert ownership and control over the property
column9: its action must also comply with the Due

column1: Syllabus
Process Clause. See
column3: Calero-Toledo v. Pearson Yacht Leasing Co.

column1: (b) An exception to the general rule requiring predeprivation notice and hearing is justified only in extraordinary situations. Id.
column2: at 82. Using the three-part inquiry set forth in Mathews v. Eldridge
column3: 424 U. S. 319-consideration of the private interest affected by the official action; the risk of an erroneous deprivation of that interest through the procedures used
column4: as well as the probable value of additional safeguards; and the Government's interest
column5: including the administrative burden that additional procedural requirements would impose
column7: at 335-the seizure of real property for purposes of civil forfeiture does not justify such an exception. Good's right to maintain control over his home
column8: and to be free from governmental interference
column9: is a private interest of historic and continuing importance
column10: cf.
column11: e. g.
column12: United States v. Karo
column15: that weighs heavily in the Mathews balance. Moreover
column16: the practice of ex parte seizure creates an unacceptable risk of error
column17: since the proceeding affords little or no protection to an innocent owner
column18: who may not be deprived of property under 881(a)(7). Nor does the governmental interest at stake here present a pressing need for prompt action. Because real property cannot abscond
column19: a court's jurisdiction can be preserved without prior seizure simply by posting notice on the property and leaving a copy of the process with the occupant. In addition
column20: the Government's legitimate interests at the inception of a forfeiture proceeding-preventing the property from being sold
column22: or used for further illegal activity before the forfeiture judgment-can be secured through measures less intrusive than seizure: a lis pendens notice to prevent the property's sale
column23: a restraining order to prevent its destruction
column24: and search and arrest warrants to forestall further illegal activity. Since a claimant is already entitled to a hearing before final judgment
column25: requiring the Government to postpone seizure until after an adversary hearing creates no significant administrative burden
column26: and any harm from the delay is minimal compared to the injury occasioned by erroneous seizure. pp. 52-59.

column1: (c) No plausible claim of executive urgency
column2: including the Government's reliance on forfeitures as a means of defraying law enforcement expenses
column3: justifies the summary seizure of real property under 881(a)(7). Cf. Phillips v. Commissioner

column1: 2. Courts may not dismiss a forfeiture action filed within the 5-year statute of limitations for noncompliance with the timing requirements of  1602-1604. Congress' failure to specify a consequence for noncompliance implies that it intended the responsible officials administering the Act to have discretion to determine what disciplinary measures are appropriate when their subordinates fail to discharge their statutory

column1: CERTIORARI TO THE UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR THE SECOND CIRCUIT
No. 92-1074. Argued October 12
Petitioner John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company (Hancock) and respondent Harris Trust and Savings Bank (Harris)
column2: the current trustee of a corporation's retirement plan
column3: are party to Group Annuity Contract No. 50 (GAC 50)
column4: an agreement of a type known as a ""participating group annuity."" Under such a contract
column5: the insurer commingles with its general corporate assets deposits received to secure retiree benefits
column6: and does not immediately apply those deposits to the purchase of annuities. During the life of the contract
column7: however
column8: amounts credited to the deposit account may be converted into a stream of guaranteed benefits for individual retirees. Funds in excess of those that have been so converted are referred to as ""free funds."" Dissatisfied over its inability to gain access to GAC 50's free funds
column9: Harris filed this suit pursuant to
column10: inter alia
column11: the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA)
column12: alleging that Hancock is managing ""plan assets
column13: and therefore is subject to ERISA's fiduciary standards in its administration of GAC 50. Hancock responded that its undertaking fits within the ERISA provision
column15: that excludes from ""plan assets"" a ""guaranteed benefit policy
column16: defined as an insurance policy or contract ""to the extent that [it] provides for benefits the amount of which is guaranteed by the insurer."" The District Court granted Hancock summary judgment on the ERISA claims
column17: holding that it was not a fiduciary with respect to any portion of GAC 50. Reversing in part
column18: the Court of Appeals held that the ""guaranteed benefit policy"" exclusion did not cover the GAC 50 free funds
column19: as to which Hancock provides no guarantee of benefit payments or fixed rates of return.

column1: Held: Because the GAC 50 free funds are ""plan assets
column2: Hancock's actions in regard to their management and disposition must be judged against ERISA's fiduciary standards. Pp.94-110.

column1: (a) The import of the pertinent ERISA provisions
column2: read as a whole and in light of the statute's broad purpose of protecting retirement benefits
column3: is reasonably clear. In contrast to other ERISA provisions creat-

column1: ing unqualified exemptions from the statute's reach
column3: by the words of limitation it used in  1101(b)(2)(B)
column4: that the guaranteed benefit policy exclusion be closely contained: The deposits over which Hancock is exercising authority or control under GAC 50 must have been obtained ""solely"" by reason of the issuance of ""an insurance policy or contract"" that provides for benefits ""the amount of which is guaranteed
column5: and even then the exemption applies only ""to the extent"" that GAC 50 provides for such benefits. Pp. 94-97.

column1: (b) The Court rejects Hancock's contention that
column2: because Congress reserved to the States primary responsibility for regulating the insurance industry
column3: ERISA's requirement that a fiduciary act ""solely in the interest of ...  participants and beneficiaries and ... for the exclusive purpose of ...  providing benefits
column5: must yield to conflicting state-law requirements that an insurer managing general account assets consider the interest of
column7: all of its contractholders
column8: creditors
column9: and shareholders. The McCarran-Ferguson Act-which provides
column10: among other things
column11: that no federal ""Act ... shall be construed to ... supersede any [state] law ...  .  enacted ... for the purpose of regulating the business of insurance ...  .  unless such Act specifically relates to the business of insurance"" -does not support Hancock's contention
column12: since ERISA and the guaranteed benefit policy provision obviously and specifically ""relat[e] to the business of insurance."" Moreover
column13: although state laws concerning an insurer's management of general account assets ""regulat[e] insurance"" in the words of ERISA's saving clause-which instructs that ERISA ""shall not be construed to exempt ... any person from any [state] law ... which regulates insurance
column14: 1144(b)(2)(A)-state laws regulating general accounts also can ""relate to [an] employee benefit plan"" under ERISA's encompassing preemption clause
column15: which directs that the statute ""shall supersede any and all State laws insofar as they ... relate to any employee benefit plan
column16: 1144(a). There is no solid basis for believing that Congress
column18: intended fundamentally to alter traditional preemption analysis. Thus
column19: ERISA leaves room for complementary or dual federal and state regulation
column20: and calls for federal supremacy when the two regimes cannot be harmonized or accommodated. pp. 97-101.

column1: (c) Hancock is an ERISA fiduciary with respect to the free funds it holds under GAC 50. To determine whether a contract qualifies as a guaranteed benefit policy
column2: each component of the contract bears examination. A component fits within the guaranteed benefit policy exclusion only if it allocates investment risk to the insurer. Cf.
column3: e. g.
column4: SEC v. United Benefit Life Ins. Co.
column5: 387 U. S. 202. Such an allocation is present when the insurer provides a genuine guarantee of an aggregate amount

column3: BY AND THROUGH HER FATHER AND NEXT FRIEND

column1: CERTIORARI TO THE UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR THE FOURTH CIRCUIT
No. 91-1523. Argued October 6
Mter respondent Shannon Carter
column2: a student in petitioner public school district
column3: was classified as learning disabled
column4: school officials met with her parents to formulate an individualized education program (IEP)
column5: as required under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA or Act)
column6: 20 U. S. C.  1400 et seq. Shannon's parents requested a hearing to challenge the proposed IEP's appropriateness. In the meantime
column7: Shannon's parents enrolled her in Trident Academy
column8: a private school specializing in educating children with disabilities. Mter the state and local educational authorities concluded that the IEP was adequate
column9: Shannon's parents filed this suit
column10: claiming that the school district had breached its duty under IDEA to provide Shannon with a ""free appropriate public education
column12: and seeking reimbursement for tuition and other costs incurred at Trident. The District Court ruled in the parents' favor
column13: holding that the proposed IEP violated IDEA
column14: and that the education Shannon received at Trident was ""appropriate"" and in substantial compliance with IDEA's substantive requirements
column15: even though the school did not comply with all of the Act's procedures. In affirming
column16: the Court of Appeals rejected the school district's argument that reimbursement is never proper when the parents choose a private school that is not approved by the State or that does not comply with all of the requirements of  1401(a)(18).

column1: Held: A court may order reimbursement for parents who unilaterally withdraw their child from a public school that provides an inappropriate education under IDEA and put the child in a private school that provides an education that is otherwise proper under IDEA
column2: but does not meet all of  1401(a)(18)'s requirements. Pp. 12-16.

column1: (a) In School Comm. of Burlington v. Department of Ed. of Mass.
column4: the Court recognized the right of parents who disagree with a proposed IEP to unilaterally withdraw their child from public school and place the child in private school
column5: and held that IDEA's grant of equitable authority empowers a court to order school authorities retroactively to reimburse the parents if the court ultimately deter-

column1: mines that the private placement
column3: is proper under the Act. P. 12.

column1: (b) Trident's failure to meet  1401(a)(18)'s definition of a ""free appropriate public education"" does not bar Shannon's parents from reimbursement
column2: because the section's requirements cannot be read as applying to parental placements. The  1401(a)(18) requirements that the education be ""provided ... under public supervision and direction
column3: and that the IEP be designed by ""a representative of the local educational agency"" and ""establish[ed]
column5: and ""review[ed]"" by the agency
column6: will never be met in the context of a parental placement. Therefore to read them as applying to parental placements would effectively eliminate the right of unilateral withdrawal recognized in Burlington
column7: and would defeat IDEA's purpose of ensuring that children with disabilities receive an education that is both appropriate and free. Similarly
column8: the  1401(a)(18)(B) requirement that the school meet the standards of the state educational agency does not apply to private parental placements. It would be inconsistent with the Act's goals to forbid parents to educate their child at a school that provides an appropriate education simply because that school lacks the stamp of approval of the same public school system that failed to meet the child's needs in the first place. Parents' failure to select a state-approved program in favor of an unapproved option does not itself bar reimbursement. Pp. 12-15.

column1: (c) The school district's argument that allowing reimbursement for parents such as Shannon's puts an unreasonable burden on financially strapped local educational authorities is rejected. Reimbursement claims need not worry school officials who conform to IDEA's mandate to either give the child a free appropriate public education in a public setting
column2: or place the child in an appropriate private setting of the State's choice. Moreover
column3: parents who unilaterally change their child's placement during the pendency of IDEA review proceedings are entitled to reimbursement only if a federal court concludes both that the public placement violated IDEA and that the private placement was proper under the Act. Finally
column4: total reimbursement will not be appropriate if a court fashioning discretionary equitable relief under IDEA determines that the cost of the private education was unreasonable. pp.15-16.

column4: and the in personam criminal forfeiture at issue here is clearly a form of monetary punishment no different

column1: CERTIORARI TO THE UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR THE NINTH CIRCUIT
No. 92-102. Argued March 30
Petitioners
column2: two minor children and their parents
column3: alleged in their suit against respondent that the children's serious birth defects had been caused by the mothers' prenatal ingestion of Bendectin
column4: a prescription drug marketed by respondent. The District Court granted respondent summary judgment based on a well-credentialed expert's affidavit concluding
column5: upon reviewing the extensive published scientific literature on the subject
column6: that maternal use of Bendectin has not been shown to be a risk factor for human birth defects. Although petitioners had responded with the testimony of eight other well-credentialed experts
column7: who based their conclusion that Bendectin can cause birth defects on animal studies
column8: chemical structure analyses
column9: and the unpublished ""reanalysis"" of previously published human statistical studies
column10: the court determined that this evidence did not meet the applicable ""general acceptance"" standard for the admission of expert testimony. The Court of Appeals agreed and affirmed
column11: citing Frye v. United States
column12: 54 App. D. C. 46
column16: for the rule that expert opinion based on a scientific technique is inadmissible unless the technique is ""generally accepted"" as reliable in the relevant scientific community.

column1: Held: The Federal Rules of Evidence
column3: provide the standard for admitting expert scientific testimony in a federal trial. Pp. 585-597.

column1: (a) Frye's ""general acceptance"" test was superseded by the Rules' adoption. The Rules occupy the field
column5: and
column6: although the common law of evidence may serve as an aid to their application
column7: id.
column9: respondent's assertion that they somehow assimilated Frye is unconvincing. Nothing in the Rules as a whole or in the text and drafting history of Rule 702
column10: which specifically governs expert testimony
column11: gives any indication that ""general acceptance"" is a necessary precondition to the admissibility of scientific evidence. Moreover
column12: such a rigid standard would be at odds with the Rules' liberal thrust and their general approach of relaxing the traditional barriers to ""opinion"" testimony. Pp. 585-589.

column1: (b) The Rules-especially Rule 702-place appropriate limits on the admissibility of purportedly scientific evidence by assigning to the trial

judge the task of ensuring that an expert's testimony both rests on a reliable foundation and is relevant to the task at hand. The reliability standard is established by Rule 702's requirement that an expert's testimony pertain to ""scientific ... knowledge
column2: since the adjective ""scientific"" implies a grounding in science's methods and procedures
column3: while the word ""knowledge"" connotes a body of known facts or of ideas inferred from such facts or accepted as true on good grounds. The Rule's requirement that the testimony ""assist the trier of fact to understand the evidence or to determine a fact in issue"" goes primarily to relevance by demanding a valid scientific connection to the pertinent inquiry as a precondition to admissibility. Pp. 589-592.

column1: (c) Faced with a proffer of expert scientific testimony under Rule 702
column3: pursuant to Rule 104(a)
column4: must make a preliminary assessment of whether the testimony's underlying reasoning or methodology is scientifically valid and properly can be applied to the facts at issue. Many considerations will bear on the inquiry
column5: including whether the theory or technique in question can be (and has been) tested
column6: whether it has been subjected to peer review and publication
column7: its known or potential error rate and the existence and maintenance of standards controlling its operation
column8: and whether it has attracted widespread acceptance within a relevant scientific community. The inquiry is a flexible one
column9: and its focus must be solely on principles and methodology
column10: not on the conclusions that they generate. Throughout
column11: the judge should also be mindful of other applicable Rules. Pp. 592-595.

column1: (d) Cross-examination
column3: and careful instruction on the burden of proof
column4: rather than wholesale exclusion under an uncompromising ""general acceptance"" standard
column5: is the appropriate means by which evidence based on valid principles may be challenged. That even limited screening by the trial judge
column7: will prevent the jury from hearing of authentic scientific breakthroughs is simply a consequence of the fact that the Rules are not designed to seek cosmic understanding but
column8: rather
column9: to resolve legal disputes. Pp.595-597.

column3: ET AL. v. MERRELL DOW PHARMACEUTICALS

column1: CERTIORARI TO THE UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR THE NINTH CIRCUIT
No. 92-102. Argued March 30
Petitioners
column2: two minor children and their parents
column3: alleged in their suit against respondent that the children's serious birth defects had been caused by the mothers' prenatal ingestion of Bendectin
column4: a prescription drug marketed by respondent. The District Court granted respondent summary judgment based on a well-credentialed expert's affidavit concluding
column5: upon reviewing the extensive published scientific literature on the subject
column6: that maternal use of Bendectin has not been shown to be a risk factor for human birth defects. Although petitioners had responded with the testimony of eight other well-credentialed experts
column7: who based their conclusion that Bendectin can cause birth defects on animal studies
column8: chemical structure analyses
column9: and the unpublished ""reanalysis"" of previously published human statistical studies
column10: the court determined that this evidence did not meet the applicable ""general acceptance"" standard for the admission of expert testimony. The Court of Appeals agreed and affirmed
column11: citing Frye v. United States
column12: 54 App. D. C. 46
column16: for the rule that expert opinion based on a scientific technique is inadmissible unless the technique is ""generally accepted"" as reliable in the relevant scientific community.

column1: Held: The Federal Rules of Evidence
column3: provide the standard for admitting expert scientific testimony in a federal trial. Pp. 585-597.

column1: (a) Frye's ""general acceptance"" test was superseded by the Rules' adoption. The Rules occupy the field
column5: and
column6: although the common law of evidence may serve as an aid to their application
column7: id.
column9: respondent's assertion that they somehow assimilated Frye is unconvincing. Nothing in the Rules as a whole or in the text and drafting history of Rule 702
column10: which specifically governs expert testimony
column11: gives any indication that ""general acceptance"" is a necessary precondition to the admissibility of scientific evidence. Moreover
column12: such a rigid standard would be at odds with the Rules' liberal thrust and their general approach of relaxing the traditional barriers to ""opinion"" testimony. Pp. 585-589.

column1: (b) The Rules-especially Rule 702-place appropriate limits on the admissibility of purportedly scientific evidence by assigning to the trial

judge the task of ensuring that an expert's testimony both rests on a reliable foundation and is relevant to the task at hand. The reliability standard is established by Rule 702's requirement that an expert's testimony pertain to ""scientific ... knowledge
column2: since the adjective ""scientific"" implies a grounding in science's methods and procedures
column3: while the word ""knowledge"" connotes a body of known facts or of ideas inferred from such facts or accepted as true on good grounds. The Rule's requirement that the testimony ""assist the trier of fact to understand the evidence or to determine a fact in issue"" goes primarily to relevance by demanding a valid scientific connection to the pertinent inquiry as a precondition to admissibility. Pp. 589-592.

column1: (c) Faced with a proffer of expert scientific testimony under Rule 702
column3: pursuant to Rule 104(a)
column4: must make a preliminary assessment of whether the testimony's underlying reasoning or methodology is scientifically valid and properly can be applied to the facts at issue. Many considerations will bear on the inquiry
column5: including whether the theory or technique in question can be (and has been) tested
column6: whether it has been subjected to peer review and publication
column7: its known or potential error rate and the existence and maintenance of standards controlling its operation
column8: and whether it has attracted widespread acceptance within a relevant scientific community. The inquiry is a flexible one
column9: and its focus must be solely on principles and methodology
column10: not on the conclusions that they generate. Throughout
column11: the judge should also be mindful of other applicable Rules. Pp. 592-595.

column1: (d) Cross-examination
column3: and careful instruction on the burden of proof
column4: rather than wholesale exclusion under an uncompromising ""general acceptance"" standard
column5: is the appropriate means by which evidence based on valid principles may be challenged. That even limited screening by the trial judge
column7: will prevent the jury from hearing of authentic scientific breakthroughs is simply a consequence of the fact that the Rules are not designed to seek cosmic understanding but
column8: rather
column9: to resolve legal disputes. Pp.595-597.

column2: the United States filed an in rem action in Federal District Court against his mobile home and auto body shop under 21 U. S. C.  881(a)(4) and (a)(7)
column3: which provide for the forfeiture of
column5: vehicles and real property used
column7: to facilitate the commission of certain drug-related crimes. In granting the Government summary judgment on the basis of an officer's affidavit that Austin had brought two grams of cocaine from the mobile home to the body shop in order to consummate a prearranged sale there
column8: the court rejected Austin's argument that forfeiture of his properties would violate the Eighth Amendment's Excessive Fines Clause. The Court of Appeals affirmed
column9: agreeing with the Government that the Eighth Amendment is inapplicable to in rem civil forfeitures.

column1: Held:
1. Forfeiture under 881(a)(4) and (a)(7) is a monetary punishment and
column3: is subject to the limitations of the Excessive Fines Clause. Pp. 606-622.

column1: (a) The determinative question is not
column2: as the Government would have it
column3: whether forfeiture under  881(a)(4) and (a)(7) is civil or criminal. The Eighth Amendment's text is not expressly limited to criminal cases
column4: and its history does not require such a limitation. Rather
column5: the crucial question is whether the forfeiture is monetary punishment
column6: with which the Excessive Fines Clause is particularly concerned. Because sanctions frequently serve more than one purpose
column7: the fact that a forfeiture serves remedial goals will not exclude it from the Clause's purview
column8: so long as it can only be explained as serving in part to punish. See United States v. Halper
column10: 448. Thus
column11: consideration must be given to whether
column12: at the time the Eighth Amendment was ratified
column13: forfeiture was understood at least in part as punishment and whether forfeiture under  881(a)( 4) and (a)(7) should be so understood today. Pp. 606-611.

column1: (b) A review of English and American law before
column3: and following the ratification of the Eighth Amendment demonstrates that forfeiture generally
column4: and statutory in rem forfeiture in particular

column1: historically have been understood
column3: as punishment. See
column5: Peisch v. Ware
column7: 364. The same understanding runs through this Court's cases rejecting the ""innocence"" of the owner as a common-law defense to forfeiture. See
column8: e. g.
column9: Calero-Toledo v. Pearson Yacht Leasing Co.

column1: (c) Forfeitures under  881 (a)(4) and (a)(7) are properly considered punishment today
column2: since nothing in these provisions contradicts the historical understanding
column3: since both sections clearly focus on the owner's culpability by expressly providing ""innocent owner"" defenses and by tying forfeiture directly to the commission of drug offenses
column4: and since the legislative history confirms that Congress understood the provisions as serving to deter and to punish. Thus
column5: even assuming that the sections serve some remedial purpose
column6: it cannot be concluded that forfeiture under the sections serves only that purpose. Pp. 619-622.

column1: 2. The Court declines to establish a test for determining whether a forfeiture is constitutionally ""excessive
column2: since prudence dictates that the lower courts be allowed to consider that question in the first instance. Pp. 622-623.

column1: APPEAL FROM THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT FOR THE EASTERN DISTRICT OF NORTH CAROLINA
No. 92-357. Argued April 20
To comply with  5 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965-which prohibits a covered jurisdiction from implementing changes in a ""standard
column3: or procedure with respect to voting"" without federal authorizationNorth Carolina submitted to the Attorney General a congressional reapportionment plan with one majority-black district. The Attorney General objected to the plan on the ground that a second district could have been created to give effect to minority voting strength in the State's south-central to southeastern region. The State's revised plan contained a second majority-black district in the north-central region. The new district stretches approximately 160 miles along Interstate 85 and
column5: is no wider than the 1-85 corridor. Appellants
column7: filed this action against appellee state and federal officials
column8: claiming that the State had created an unconstitutional racial gerrymander in violation of
column9: among other things
column10: the Fourteenth Amendment. They alleged that the two districts concentrated a majority of black voters arbitrarily without regard to considerations such as compactness
column11: contiguousness
column12: geographical boundaries
column14: in order to create congressional districts along racial lines and to assure the election of two black representatives. The three-judge District Court held that it lacked subject matter jurisdiction over the federal appellees. It also dismissed the complaint against the state appellees
column15: finding
column18: under United Jewish Organizations of Williams burgh
column21: appellants had failed to state an equal protection claim because favoring minority voters was not discriminatory in the constitutional sense and the plan did not lead to proportional underrepresentation of white voters statewide.

column1: Held:

1. Appellants have stated a claim under the Equal Protection Clause by alleging that the reapportionment scheme is so irrational on its face that it can be understood only as an effort to segregate voters into separate districts on the basis of race
column2: and that the separation lacks sufficient justification. Pp. 639-652.

column1: (a) The District Court properly dismissed the claims against the federal appellees. Appellants' racial gerrymandering claims must be examined against the backdrop of this country's long history of racial discrimination in voting. Pp. 639-642.
(b) Classifications of citizens based solely on race are by their nature odious to a free people whose institutions are founded upon the doctrine of equality
column2: because they threaten to stigmatize persons by reason of their membership in a racial group and to incite racial hostility. Thus
column3: state legislation that expressly distinguishes among citizens on account of race-whether it contains an explicit distinction or is ""unexplainable on grounds other than race
column4: Arlington Heights v. Metropolitan Housing Development Corp.
column6: 266-must be narrowly tailored to further a compelling governmental interest. See
column7: e. g.
column8: Wygant v. Jackson Ed. of Ed.
column10: 277-278 (plurality opinion). Redistricting legislation that is alleged to be so bizarre on its face that it is unexplainable on grounds other than race demands the same close scrutiny
column11: regardless of the motivations underlying its adoption. See
column12: e. g.
column15: 341. That it may be difficult to determine from the face of a single-member districting plan that it makes such a distinction does not mean that a racial gerrymander
column17: should receive less scrutiny than other legislation classifying citizens by race. By perpetuating stereotypical notions about members of the same racial group-that they think alike
column19: and prefer the same candidates-a racial gerrymander may exacerbate the very patterns of racial bloc voting that majority-minority districting is sometimes said to counteract. It also sends to elected representatives the message that their primary obligation is to represent only that group's members
column20: rather than their constituency as a whole. Since the holding here makes it unnecessary to decide whether or how a reapportionment plan that
column22: can be explained in nonracial terms successfully could be challenged
column23: the Court expresses no view on whether the intentional creation of majorityminority districts
column25: always gives rise to an equal protection claim. Pp. 642-649.

UNITED STATES v. DIXON ET AL.
CERTIORARI TO THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA COURT OF APPEALS
No.91-1231. Argued December 2
Based on respondent Dixon's arrest and indictment for possession of cocaine with intent to distribute
column2: he was convicted of criminal contempt for violating a condition of his release on an unrelated offense forbidding him to commit ""any criminal offense."" The trial court later dismissed the cocaine indictment on double jeopardy grounds. Conversely
column3: the trial court in respondent Foster's case ruled that double jeopardy did not require dismissal of a five-count indictment charging him with simple assault (Count I)
column4: threatening to injure another on three occasions (Counts II-IV)
column5: and assault with intent to kill (Count V)
column6: even though the events underlying the charges had previously prompted his trial for criminal contempt for violating a civil protection order (CPO) requiring him not to ""'assault ... or in any manner threaten .. .''' his estranged wife. The District of Columbia Court of Appeals consolidated the two cases on appeal and ruled that both subsequent prosecutions were barred by the Double Jeopardy Clause under Grady v. Corbin

column1: Held: The judgment is affirmed in part and reversed in part

column3: reversed in part

column1: JUSTICE SCALIA delivered the opinion of the Court with respect to Parts I
column3: and IV

column1: 1. The Double Jeopardy Clause's protection attaches in nonsummary criminal contempt prosecutions just as it does in other criminal prosecutions. In the contexts of both multiple punishments and successive prosecution
column2: the double jeopardy bar applies if the two offenses for which the defendant is punished or tried cannot survive the ""sameelements"" or ""Block burger"" test. See
column3: e. g.
column6: 304. That test inquires whether each offense contains an element not contained in the other; if not
column7: they are the ""same offence"" within the Clause's meaning
column8: and double jeopardy bars subsequent punishment or prosecution. The Court recently held in Grady that in addition to passing the Blockburger test
column9: a subsequent prosecution must satisfy a ""same-conduct"" test to avoid the double jeopardy bar. That test provides that
column10: ""if
column11: to establish an essential element of an offense charged in that prosecution
column12: the government will prove conduct

column1: that constitutes an offense for which the defendant has already been prosecuted
column2: a second prosecution may not be had. 495 U. S.

column1: 2. Although prosecution under Counts II-V of Foster's indictment would undoubtedly be barred by the Grady ""same-conduct"" test
column2: Grady must be overruled because it contradicted an unbroken line of decisions
column3: contained less than accurate historical analysis
column4: and has produced confusion. Unlike Blockburger analysis
column5: the Grady test lacks constitutional roots. It is wholly inconsistent with this Court's precedents and with the clear common-law understanding of double jeopardy. See Grady
column7: at 526 (SCALIA
column8: J.
column9: dissenting). In re Nielsen
column11: and subsequent cases stand for propositions that are entirely in accord with Blockburger and that do not establish even minimal antecedents for the Grady rule. In contrast
column12: two post-Nielsen cases
column19: upheld subsequent prosecutions because the Blockburger test (and only the Blockburger test) was satisfied. Moreover
column20: the Grady rule has already proved unstable in application
column22: 503 U. S. 378. Although the Court does not lightly reconsider precedent
column23: it has never felt constrained to follow prior decisions that are unworkable or badly reasoned. Pp.703-712.

column1: JUSTICE SCALIA
column3: concluded in Part III that:

column1: 1. Because Dixon's drug offense did not include any element not contained in his previous contempt offense
column2: his subsequent prosecution fails the Blockburger test. Dixon's contempt sanction was imposed for violating the order through commission of the incorporated drug offense. His ""crime"" of violating a condition of his release cannot be abstracted from the ""element"" of the violated condition. Harris v. Oklahoma
column3: 433 U. S. 682 (per curiam). Here
column5: the underlying substantive criminal offense is a ""species of lesser-included offense
column9: whose subsequent prosecution is barred by the Double Jeopardy Clause. The same analysis applies to Count I of Foster's indictment
column10: and that prosecution is barred. Pp. 697-700.

column1: 2. However
column2: the remaining four counts of Foster's indictment are not barred under Blockburger. Foster's first prosecution for violating the CPO provision forbidding him to assault his wife does not bar his later prosecution under Count V
column3: which charges assault with intent to kill. That offense requires proof of specific intent to kill
column4: which the contempt offense did not. Similarly
column5: the contempt crime required proof of knowledge of the CPO
column6: which the later charge does not. The two crimes were different offenses under the Blockburger test. Counts II
column7: III
column8: and IV are likewise not barred. pp. 700-703.

CERTIORARI TO THE UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR THE SEVENTH CIRCUIT

Petitioner Buckley sought damages
column3: from respondent prosecutors for fabricating evidence during the preliminary investigation of a highly publicized rape and murder in Illinois and making false statements at a press conference announcing the return of an indictment against him. He claimed that when three separate lab studies failed to make a reliable connection between a bootprint at the murder site and his boots
column4: respondents obtained a positive identification from one Robbins
column5: who allegedly was known for her willingness to fabricate unreliable expert testimony. Thereafter
column6: they convened a grand jury for the sole purpose of investigating the murder
column7: and 10 months later
column8: respondent Fitzsimmons
column9: the State's Attorney
column10: announced the indictment at the news conference. Buckley was arrested and
column11: unable to meet the bond
column12: held in jail. Robbins provided the principal evidence against him at trial
column13: but the jury was unable to reach a verdict. When Robbins died before Buckley's retrial
column14: all charges were dropped and he was released after three years of incarceration. In the  1983 action
column15: the District Court held that respondents were entitled to absolute immunity for the fabricated evidence claim but not for the press conference claim. However
column16: the Court of Appeals ruled that they had absolute immunity on both claims
column17: theorizing that prosecutors are entitled to absolute immunity when out-of-court acts cause injury only to the extent a case proceeds in court
column18: but are entitled only to qualified immunity if the constitutional wrong is complete before the case begins. On remand from this Court
column19: it found that nothing in Burns v. Reed
column20: 500 U. S. 478-in which the Court held that prosecutors had absolute immunity for their actions in participating in a probable-cause hearing but not in giving advice to the police-undermined its initial holding.

column1: Held: Respondents are not entitled to absolute immunity. Pp. 267-278.

(a) Certain immunities were so well established when  1983 was enacted that this Court presumes that Congress would have specifically so provided had it wished to abolish them. Most public officials are entitled only to qualified immunity. However
column2: sometimes their actions fit within a common-law tradition of absolute immunity. Whether they do is determined by the nature of the function performed
column3: not the identity of the actor who performed it

column1: Syllabus
and it is available for conduct of prosecutors that is ""intimately associated with the judicial phase of the criminal process."" Imbler v. Pachtman
(b) Acts undertaken by a prosecutor in preparing for the initiation of judicial proceedings or for trial
column2: and which occur in the course of his role as an advocate for the State
column3: are entitled to the protections of absolute immunity. However
column4: in endeavoring to determine whether the bootprint had been made by Buckley
column5: respondents were acting not as advocates but as investigators searching for clues and corroboration that might give them probable cause to recommend an arrest. Such activities were not immune from liability at common law. If performed by police officers and detectives
column6: such actions would be entitled to only qualified immunity; the same immunity applies to prosecutors performing those actions. Convening a grand jury to consider the evidence their work produced does not retroactively transform that work from the administrative into the prosecutorial. Pp.271-276.

column1: (c) Fitzsimmons' statements to the media also are not entitled to absolute immunity. There was no common-law immunity for prosecutor's out-of-court statements to the press
column3: under Imbler
column4: such comments have no functional tie to the judicial process just because they are made by a prosecutor. Nor do policy considerations support extending absolute immunity to press statements
column5: since this Court has no license to establish immunities from  1983 actions in the interests of what it judges to be sound public policy
column6: and since the presumption is that qualified
column7: rather than absolute
column8: immunity is sufficient to protect government officials in the exercise of their duties. Pp. 276-278.

column1: CERTIORARI TO THE UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR THE EIGHTH CIRCUIT
No.92-311. Argued March 31

column2: respondent Schaefer filed a claim for Social Security disability benefits
column3: which was denied by petitioner Secretary at the administrative level. Schaefer sought judicial review and
column6: the District Court reversed the administrative denial of benefits and remanded the case to the Secretary pursuant to the fourth sentence of 42 U. S. C.  405(g). Schaefer was awarded benefits on remand and
column7: in July 1990
column8: he returned to the District Court and filed for attorney's fees under the Equal Access to Justice Act (EAJA). In opposing the motion
column9: the Secretary noted that the EAJA required Schaefer to file his application within 30 days of ""final judgment"" in the action
column11: and argued that the 30-day clock began running when the District Court's sentence-four remand order of April 4
column14: which would have occurred at the end of the 60 days for appeal provided under Federal Rule of Appellate Procedure 4(a). The District Court awarded fees to Schaefer
column15: holding that a sentence-four remand order is not a final judgment where a court retains jurisdiction and plans to enter a judgment after remand proceedings are complete. The Court of Appeals affirmed on the same basis.

column1: Held:
1. The 30-day period for filing an application for EAJA fees begins immediately upon expiration of the time for appeal of a ""sentence-four remand order."" Pp. 295-302.

(a) A district court remanding a case pursuant to sentence four of  405(g) must enter judgment in the case and may not retain jurisdiction over the administrative proceedings on remand. Sentence four's plain language authorizes a court to enter a judgment ""with or without remanding the cause for a rehearing
column2: not a remand order ""with or without"" a judgment. Pp. 295-297.

column1: (b) The Court's decision in Sullivan v. Hudson
column3: 892that fees incurred during administrative proceedings held pursuant to a district court's remand order may be recovered under the EAJA-does not apply where the remand is ordered pursuant to sentence four of  405(g). Pp. 298-300.

column1: (c) Contrary to dicta in Sullivan v. Hudson
column2: a Social Security claimant who obtains a sentence-four judgment reversing the Secretary's denial of benefits meets the description of a ""prevailing party"" set out in Texas State Teachers Assn. v. Garland Independent School Dist.

column1: 2. Schaefer's application for EAJA fees was nonetheless timely under  2412(d)(1) because the District Court failed to comply with Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 58 in entering its sentence-four remand order of April 4
column2: 1989. The EAJA's 30-day time limit runs from the end of the period for appeal
column3: and that period does not begin until a judgment is entered in compliance with the formalities of Rule 58. Because the District Court never entered formal judgment
column4: neither the time for appeal nor the EAJA's 30-day clock had run when Schaefer filed his application. Pp. 302-303.

column3: KENTUCKY CABINET FOR HUMAN RESOURCES v. DOE

column1: CERTIORARI TO THE UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR THE SIXTH CIRCUIT
No.92-351. Argued March 22
Kentucky permits the involuntary commitment of mentally retarded or mentally ill individuals who present a threat of danger to themselves
column3: or others
column4: who can reasonably benefit from the available treatment
column5: and for whom the least restrictive alternative is placement in the relevant facility. However
column6: the statutory procedures for the commitment of the two groups differ in the two respects at issue here. First
column7: the applicable burden of proof in mental retardation commitment proceedings is clear and convincing evidence while the standard in mental illness proceedings is beyond a reasonable doubt. Second
column8: guardians and immediate family members of the subject of a mental retardation proceeding may participate as if parties to those proceedings
column9: with all attendant rights. In this action
column10: respondents
column11: a class of involuntarily committed mentally retarded persons
column12: claimed that the distinctions are irrational and therefore violate the Fourteenth Amendment's Equal Protection Clause
column13: and that granting close family members and guardians the status of parties violates the Due Process Clause. The District Court granted them summary judgment
column14: and the Court of Appeals affirmed.

column1: Held:
1. Respondents' claim that the statutes should be reviewed under a heightened scrutiny standard is not properly presented

column4: and the State Supreme Court dismissed his appeal. A Federal District Court denied his petition for a writ of habeas corpus

In a consolidated appeal from decisions by the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) to initiate administrative sanctions against petitioners
column2: an Administrative Law Judge (ALJ) concluded that petitioners should be debarred from participating in federal programs for 18 months. Under HUD regulations
column3: an ALJ's determination ""shall be final unless ... the Secretary ... within 30 days of receipt of a request decides as a matter of discretion to review the [ALJ's] finding .... "" 24 CFR 24.314(c). Neither party sought further administrative review
column4: but petitioners filed suit in the District Court
column5: seeking an injunction and declaration that the sanctions were not in accordance with law within the meaning of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA). Respondents moved to dismiss the complaint on the ground that petitioners
column6: by forgoing the option to seek review by the Secretary
column7: had failed to exhaust their administrative remedies. The court denied the motion and granted summary judgment to petitioners on the merits of the case. The Court of Appeals reversed
column8: holding that the District Court had erred in denying the motion to dismiss.

column1: Held: Federal courts do not have the authority to require a plaintiff to exhaust available administrative remedies before seeking judicial review under the APA
column2: where neither the relevant statute nor agency rules specifically mandate exhaustion as a prerequisite to judicial review. The language of  10(c) of the APA is explicit that an appeal to ""superior agency authority"" is a prerequisite to judicial review only when ""expressly required by statute"" or when the agency requires an appeal ""by rule and provides that the [administrative] action is ... inoperative"" pending that review. Since neither the National Housing Act nor applicable HUD regulations mandate further administrative appeals
column3: the ALJ's decision was a ""final"" agency action subject to judicial review under  10(c). The lower courts were not free to require further exhaustion of administrative remedies
column4: although the exhaustion doctrine continues to apply as a matter of judicial discretion in cases not gov-

column1: erned by the APA. Nothing in  10(c)'s legislative history supports a contrary reading. Pp. 143-154.

column1: CERTIORARI TO THE UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR THE FOURTH CIRCUIT
No. 91-2045. Argued March 22
In a consolidated appeal from decisions by the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) to initiate administrative sanctions against petitioners
column2: an Administrative Law Judge (ALJ) concluded that petitioners should be debarred from participating in federal programs for 18 months. Under HUD regulations
column3: an ALJ's determination ""shall be final unless ... the Secretary ... within 30 days of receipt of a request decides as a matter of discretion to review the [ALJ's] finding .... "" 24 CFR 24.314(c). Neither party sought further administrative review
column4: but petitioners filed suit in the District Court
column5: seeking an injunction and declaration that the sanctions were not in accordance with law within the meaning of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA). Respondents moved to dismiss the complaint on the ground that petitioners
column6: by forgoing the option to seek review by the Secretary
column7: had failed to exhaust their administrative remedies. The court denied the motion and granted summary judgment to petitioners on the merits of the case. The Court of Appeals reversed
column8: holding that the District Court had erred in denying the motion to dismiss.

column1: Held: Federal courts do not have the authority to require a plaintiff to exhaust available administrative remedies before seeking judicial review under the APA
column2: where neither the relevant statute nor agency rules specifically mandate exhaustion as a prerequisite to judicial review. The language of  10(c) of the APA is explicit that an appeal to ""superior agency authority"" is a prerequisite to judicial review only when ""expressly required by statute"" or when the agency requires an appeal ""by rule and provides that the [administrative] action is ... inoperative"" pending that review. Since neither the National Housing Act nor applicable HUD regulations mandate further administrative appeals
column3: the ALJ's decision was a ""final"" agency action subject to judicial review under  10(c). The lower courts were not free to require further exhaustion of administrative remedies
column4: although the exhaustion doctrine continues to apply as a matter of judicial discretion in cases not gov-

column1: erned by the APA. Nothing in  10(c)'s legislative history supports a contrary reading. Pp. 143-154.

Cigarette manufacturing is a concentrated industry dominated by only six firms
column2: including the two parties here. In 1980
column3: petitioner (hereinafter Liggett) pioneered the economy segment of the market by developing a line of generic cigarettes offered at a list price roughly 30% lower than that of branded cigarettes. By 1984
column4: generics had captured 4% of the market
column5: at the expense of branded cigarettes
column6: and respondent Brown & Williamson entered the economy segment
column7: beating Liggett's net price. Liggett responded in kind
column8: precipitating a price war
column9: which ended
column10: according to Liggett
column11: with Brown & Williamson selling its generics at a loss. Liggett filed this suit
column12: alleging
column14: that volume rebates by Brown & Williamson to wholesalers amounted to price discrimination that had a reasonable possibility of injuring competition in violation of  2(a) of the Clayton Act
column15: as amended by the Robinson-Patman Act. Liggett claimed that the rebates were integral to a predatory pricing scheme
column16: in which Brown & Williamson set below-cost prices to pressure Liggett to raise list prices on its generics
column17: thus restraining the economy segment's growth and preserving Brown & Williamson's supracompetitive profits on branded cigarettes. Mter a jury returned a verdict in favor of Liggett
column18: the District Court held that Brown & Williamson was entitled to judgment as a matter of law. Among other things

column1: Held: Brown & Williamson is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.
(a) The Robinson-Patman Act
column3: condemns price discrimination only to the extent that it threatens to injure competition. A claim of primary-line competitive injury under the Act
column5: is of the same general character as a predatory pricing claim under  2 of the Sherman Act: A business rival has priced its products in an unfair manner with an object to eliminate or retard competition and thereby gain and exercise control over prices in the relevant market.

column3: distinguished. Accordingly
column4: two prerequisites to recovery are also the same. A plaintiff must prove (1) that the prices complained of are below an appropriate measure of its rival's costs and (2) that the competitor had a reasonable prospect of recouping its investment in below-cost prices. Without recoupment
column5: even if predatory pricing causes the target painful losses
column6: it produces lower aggregate prices in the market
column7: and consumer welfare is enhanced. For recoupment to occur
column8: the pricing must be capable
column9: as a threshold matter
column10: of producing the intended effects on the firm's rivals. This requires an understanding of the extent and duration of the alleged predation
column11: the relative financial strength of the predator and its intended victim
column12: and their respective incentives and will. The inquiry is whether
column13: given the aggregate losses caused by the belowcost pricing
column14: the intended target would likely succumb. If so
column15: then there is the further question whether the below-cost pricing would likely injure competition in the relevant market. The plaintiff must demonstrate that there is a likelihood that the scheme alleged would cause a rise in prices above a competitive level sufficient to compensate for the amounts expended on the predation
column16: including the time value of the money invested in it. Evidence of below-cost pricing is not alone sufficient to permit an inference of probable recoupment and injury to competition. The determination requires an estimate of the alleged predation's cost and a close analysis of both the scheme alleged and the relevant market's structure and conditions. Although not easy to establish
column17: these prerequisites are essential components of real market injury. Pp. 219-227.

column1: (b) An oligopoly's interdependent pricing may provide a means for achieving recoupment and thus may form the basis of a primary-line injury claim. Predatory pricing schemes
column3: are implausible
column4: see Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. v. Zenith Radio Corp.
column7: and are even more improbable when they require coordinated action among several firms
column8: id.
column9: at 590. They are least likely to occur where
column10: as alleged here
column11: the cooperation among firms is tacit
column12: since effective tacit coordination is difficult to achieve; since there is a high likelihood that any attempt by one oligopolist to discipline a rival by cutting prices will produce an outbreak of competition; and since a predator's present losses fall on it alone
column13: while the later supracompetitive profits must be shared with every other oligopolist in proportion to its market share
column15: the Robinson-Patman Act suggests no exclusion from coverage when primary-line injury occurs in an oligopoly setting
column16: and this Court declines to create a per se rule of nonliability. In order for all of the Act's words to carry adequate meaning
column17: competitive injury under the Act must extend beyond the monopoly setting. Pp. 227-230.

ZOBREST ET AL. v. CATALINA FOOTHILLS SCHOOL DISTRICT
CERTIORARI TO THE UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR THE NINTH CIRCUIT
No. 92-94. Argued February 24
Petitioners
column2: a deaf child and his parents
column3: filed this suit after respondent school district refused to provide a sign-language interpreter to accompany the child to classes at a Roman Catholic high school. They alleged that the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) and the Free Exercise Clause of the First Amendment required respondent to provide the interpreter and that the Establishment Clause did not bar such relief. The District Court granted respondent summary judgment on the ground that the interpreter would act as a conduit for the child's religious inculcation
column4: thereby promoting his religious development at government expense in violation of the Establishment Clause. The Court of Appeals affirmed.

column1: Held:
1. The prudential rule of avoiding constitutional questions if there is a nonconstitutional ground for decision is inapplicable here
column2: since respondent did not urge upon the District Court or the Court of Appeals any of the nonconstitutional grounds it now raises in this Court. Pp.6-8.

column1: 2. The Establishment Clause does not prevent respondent from furnishing a disabled child enrolled in a sectarian school with a signlanguage interpreter in order to facilitate his education. Government programs that neutrally provide benefits to a broad class of citizens defined without reference to religion are not readily subject to an Establishment Clause challenge just because sectarian institutions may also
receive an attenuated financial benefit. Mueller v. Allen
column2: 463 U. S. 388; Witters v. Washington Dept. of Services for Blind
column3: 474 U. S. 481. The same reasoning used in Mueller and Witters applies here. The service in this case is part of a general government program that distributes benefits neutrally to any child qualifying as disabled under the IDEA
column5: or public-nonpublic nature of the school the child attends. By according parents freedom to select a school of their choice
column6: the statute ensures that a government-paid interpreter will be present in a sectarian school only as a result of individual parents' private decisions. Since the IDEA creates no financial incentive for parents to choose a sectarian school
column7: an interpreter's presence there cannot be attributed to state decisionmaking. The fact that a public employee will be physically present in a sectarian school does not by itself make this the same type of aid that was disapproved in Meek v. Pittenger
column9: and School Dist. of Grand Rapids v. Ball
column10: 473 U. S. 373. In those cases
column11: the challenged programs gave direct grants of government aid-instructional equipment and material
column12: teachers
column13: and guidance counselors-which relieved sectarian schools of costs they otherwise would have borne in educating their students. Here
column14: the child is the primary beneficiary
column15: and the school receives only an incidental benefit. In addition
column17: unlike a teacher or guidance counselor
column18: neither adds to nor subtracts from the sectarian school's environment but merely interprets whatever material is presented to the class as a whole. There is no absolute bar to the placing of a public employee in a sectarian school. Pp.8-14.

column3: 1391. Withdrawal liability is assessed by means of a notification by the ""plan sponsor"" and a demand for payment.  1399(b). An unresolved dispute is referred to arbitration

column7: ""the actuarial assumptions and methods"" used in a calculation ""were

column2: the statute is incoherent with respect to the degree of certainty required to overturn a plan sponsor's factual determination. In light of the assumed bias

The uncertainty raised by this incoherent statute is resolved by applying the canon requiring that an ambiguous statute be construed to avoid serious constitutional problems unless such construction is plainly contrary to Congress's intent. Respondent city enacted an ordinance requiring that 10% of the amount spent on city contracts be set aside each fiscal year for so-called ""Minority Business Enterprises"" (MBE's). Petitioner construction contractors' association
column2: most of whose members did not qualify as MBE's
column3: filed suit in the District Court against the city and respondent mayor
column4: alleging that many of its members regularly bid on
column5: and performed
column6: construction work for the city and ""would have ... bid on ... designated set aside contracts but for the restrictions imposed"" by the ordinance in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment's Equal Protection Clause. Ultimately the court entered summary judgment for petitioner
column7: but the Court of Appeals vacated the judgment
column8: ruling that petitioner lacked standing to challenge the ordinance because it had ""not demonstrated that
column9: but for the program
column10: any ... member would have bid successfully for any of [the] contracts."" Mter certiorari was granted
column11: the city repealed its MBE ordinance
column12: replacing it with another ordinance which
column13: although different from the repealed ordinance
column14: still set aside certain contracts for certified black- and female-owned businesses. Subsequently
column15: this Court denied respondents' motion to dismiss the case as moot.

column1: Held:
1. The case is not moot. It is well settled that the voluntary cessation of a challenged practice does not deprive a federal court of its power to determine the practice's legality
column2: because a defendant is not precluded from reinstating the practice. Here
column3: there is more than a mere risk that the city will repeat its allegedly wrongful conduct; it has already done so. Insofar as the city's new ordinance accords preferential treatment in the award of city contracts
column4: it disadvantages petitioner's members in the same way that the repealed ordinance did. Pp. 661-663.

column1: 2. Petitioner has standing to sue the city. Pp. 663-669.
(a) When the government erects a barrier that makes it more difficult for members of one group to obtain a benefit than it is for members of another group
column2: a member of the former group seeking to challenge the barrier need not allege that he would have obtained the benefit but for the barrier in order to establish standing. See
column3: e. g.
column4: Regents of Univ. of Cal. v. Bakke
column5: 438 U. S. 265. The ""injury in fact"" element of standing in such an equal protection case is the denial of equal treatment resulting from the imposition of the barrier-here
column6: the inability to compete on an equal footing in the bidding process-not the ultimate inability to obtain the benefit. To establish standing
column7: therefore
column8: petitioner need only demonstrate that its members are able and ready to bid on contracts and that a discriminatory policy prevents them from doing so on an equal basis. Pp. 663-666.

column1: (b) Respondents' reliance on Warth v. Seldin
column2: 422 U. S. 490-in which a construction association was denied standing to challenge a town's zoning ordinance-is misplaced. Unlike petitioner
column3: the association in Warth claimed that its members could not obtain variances and permits
column4: not that they could not apply for the variances and permits on an equal basis
column5: and did not allege that any members had applied for a permit or variance for a current project. Pp. 666-668.

column1: (c) Petitioner's allegations that its members regularly bid on city contracts and would have bid on the contracts set aside under the ordinance were unchallenged and are assumed to be true. Pp. 668-669. 951 F.2d 1217

column4: subject to evidentiary rules dealing with relevancy
column5: reliability
column6: and the like. Haupt v. United States

Syllabus
MINNESOTA v. DICKERSON
CERTIORARI TO THE SUPREME COURT OF MINNESOTA No. 91-2019. Argued March 3
Based upon respondent's seemingly evasive actions when approached by police officers and the fact that he had just left a building known for cocaine traffic
column2: the officers decided to investigate further and ordered respondent to submit to a patdown search. The search revealed no weapons
column3: but the officer conducting it testified that he felt a small lump in respondent's jacket pocket
column4: believed it to be a lump of crack cocaine upon examining it with his fingers
column5: and then reached into the pocket and retrieved a small bag of cocaine. The state trial court denied respondent's motion to suppress the cocaine
column6: and he was found guilty of possession of a controlled substance. The Minnesota Court of Appeals reversed. In affirming
column7: the State Supreme Court held that both the stop and the frisk of respondent were valid under Terry v. Ohio
column9: but found the seizure of the cocaine to be unconstitutional. Refusing to enlarge the ""plain-view"" exception to the Fourth Amendment's warrant requirement
column10: the court appeared to adopt a categorical rule barring the seizure of any contraband detected by an officer through the sense of touch during a patdown search. The court further noted that
column11: even if it recognized such a ""plain-feel"" exception
column12: the search in this case would not qualify because it went far beyond what is permissible under Terry.

column1: Held:
1. The police may seize nonthreatening contraband detected through the sense of touch during a protective patdown search of the sort permitted by Terry
column2: so long as the search stays within the bounds marked by Terry. pp.372-377.

column1: (a) Terry permits a brief stop of a person whose suspicious conduct leads an officer to conclude in light of his experience that criminal activity may be afoot
column2: and a patdown search of the person for weapons when the officer is justified in believing that the person may be armed and presently dangerous. This protective search-permitted without a warrant and on the basis of reasonable suspicion less than probable cause-is not meant to discover evidence of crime
column3: but must be strictly limited to that which is necessary for the discovery of weapons which might be used to harm the officer or others. If the protective search goes beyond what is necessary to determine if the suspect is armed

column1: is no longer valid under Terry and its fruits will be suppressed. Sibron v. New York
(b) In Michigan v. Long
column4: the seizure of contraband other than weapons during a lawful Terry search was justified by reference to the Court's cases under the ""plain-view"" doctrine. That doctrine-which permits police to seize an object without a warrant if they are lawfully in a position to view it
column5: if its incriminating character is immediately apparent
column6: and if they have a lawful right of access to it-has an obvious application by analogy to cases in which an officer discovers contraband through the sense of touch during an otherwise lawful search. Thus
column7: if an officer lawfully pats down a suspect's outer clothing and feels an object whose contour or mass makes its identity immediately apparent
column8: there has been no invasion of the suspect's privacy beyond that already authorized by the officer's search for weapons. Cf.
column9: e. g.
column10: Illinois v. Andreas
column12: 771. If the object is contraband
column13: its warrantless seizure would be justified by the realization that resort to a neutral magistrate under such circumstances would be impracticable and would do little to promote the Fourth Amendment's objectives. Cf.
column15: Arizona v. Hicks

column1: 2. Application of the foregoing principles to the facts of this case demonstrates that the officer who conducted the search was not acting within the lawful bounds marked by Terry at the time he gained probable cause to believe that the lump in respondent's jacket was contraband. Under the State Supreme Court's interpretation of the record
column2: the officer never thought that the lump was a weapon
column3: but did not immediately recognize it as cocaine. Rather
column4: he determined that it was contraband only after he squeezed
column5: slid
column6: and otherwise manipulated the pocket's contents. While Terry entitled him to place his hands on respondent's jacket and to feel the lump in the pocket
column7: his continued exploration of the pocket after he concluded that it contained no weapon was unrelated to the sole justification for the search under Terry. Because this further search was constitutionally invalid
column8: the seizure of the cocaine that followed is likewise unconstitutional. Pp. 377-379.

LAMB'S CHAPEL ET AL. v. CENTER MORICHES UNION FREE SCHOOL DISTRICT ET AL.
CERTIORARI TO THE UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR THE SECOND CIRCUIT
No. 91-2024. Argued February 24
New York law authorizes local school boards to adopt reasonable regulations permitting the after-hours use of school property for 10 specified purposes
column2: not including meetings for religious purposes. Pursuant to this law
column3: respondent school board (District) issued rules and regulations allowing
column5: social
column7: and recreational uses of its schools (Rule 10)
column8: but prohibiting use by any group for religious purposes (Rule 7). Mter the District refused two requests by petitioners
column9: an evangelical church and its pastor (Church)
column10: to use school facilities for a religious oriented film series on family values and child rearing on the ground that the film series appeared to be church related
column11: the Church filed suit in the District Court
column12: claiming that the District's actions violated
column14: the First Amendment's Freedom of Speech Clause. The court granted summary judgment to the District
column15: and the Court of Appeals affirmed. It reasoned that the school property
column16: as a ""limited public forum"" open only for designated purposes
column17: remained nonpublic except for the specified purposes
column18: and ruled that the exclusion of the Church's film was reasonable and viewpoint neutral.

column1: Held: Denying the Church access to school premises to exhibit the film series violates the Freedom of Speech Clause. Pp. 390-397.

(a) There is no question that the District may legally preserve the property under its control and need not have permitted after-hours use for any of the uses permitted under state law. This Court need not address the issue whether Rule 10
column2: by opening the property to a wide variety of communicative purposes
column3: has opened the property for religious uses
column5: even if the District has not opened its property for such uses
column6: Rule 7 has been unconstitutionally applied in this case. Access to a nonpublic forum can be based on subject matter or speaker identity so long as the distinctions drawn are reasonable and viewpoint neutral. Cornelius v. NAACP Legal Defense and Ed. Fund
column7: Inc.
column9: 806. That Rule 7 treats all religions and religious purposes alike does not make its application in this case viewpoint neutral
column10: however
column11: for it discriminates on the basis of viewpoint by permitting school property to be used for the presentation of all views about family issues and child rearing except those dealing with the subject from a religious

column1: standpoint. Denial on this basis is plainly invalid under the holding in Cornelius
column3: at 806
column4: that the government violates the First Amendment when it denies access to a speaker solely to suppress the point of view he espouses on an otherwise includible subject. Pp. 390-394.

column1: (b) Permitting District property to be used to exhibit the film series would not have been an establishment of religion under the three-part test articulated in Lemon v. Kurtzman
column2: 403 U. S. 602. Since the series would not have been shown during school hours
column3: would not have been sponsored by the school
column4: and would have been open to the public
column5: there would be no realistic danger that the community would think that the District was endorsing religion or any particular creed
column6: and any benefit to religion or the Church would have been incidental. Widmar v. Vincent
column8: 271-272. Nor is there anything in the record to support the claim that the exclusion was justified on the ground that allowing access to a ""radical"" church would lead to threats of public unrest and violence. In addition
column9: the Court of Appeals' judgment was not based on the justification proffered here that the access rules' purpose is to promote the interests of the general public rather than sectarian or other private interests. Moreover
column10: that there was no express finding below that the Church's application would have been granted absent the religious connection is beside the point for the purposes of this opinion
column11: which is concerned with the validity of the stated reason for denying the application
column12: namely
column13: that the film series appeared to be church related. Pp.395-397.
